title: 108_hr4851
content:
Step 1 - Extractively Summarize the curr_chunk, try to preserve key details, and condense the text by removing irrelevant words:

"S."

Step 4: Output the summarized chunk

"S." The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a spending limitation for fiscal year 2006 and beyond. A new point of order is added to prevent consideration of any spending exceeding the limitation in the House of Representatives or the Senate. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a spending limitation for fiscal year 2006 and beyond, with a new point of order added to prevent consideration of any spending exceeding the limitation in the House of Representatives or the Senate. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a spending limitation for fiscal year 2006 and beyond. A new point of order is added to prevent consideration of any spending exceeding the limitation in the House of Representatives or the Senate, requiring a two-thirds vote to waive or suspend it. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a spending limitation for fiscal year 2006 and beyond. A two-thirds vote is required in the House of Representatives or the Senate to waive or suspend the spending limitation. In the Senate, an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the Members is needed to sustain an appeal of the chair's ruling on a point of order. Appeals in the Senate are limited to one hour and divided between the mover and the manager of the concurrent resolution. SEC. 13. REDUCTION OF FICA RATES RESULTING FROM PERSONAL SOCIAL SECURITY SAVINGS PROGRAM. Employee Contribution: Section 3101 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to reduce the tax rate on employees for Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance in years following a reduction year where the OASDI rate ratio exceeds 125 percent. The tax rate on employees for Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance will be reduced each year after a reduction year where the OASDI rate ratio exceeds 125 percent. The reduction percentage will be applied to the rate of tax imposed under subsection (a). The reduction percentage is the difference between the rate in effect for the reduction year and the rounded-up rate for the same year. The reduction percentage, as defined in the Prosperity Act of 2004, is the difference between the rate in effect for the reduction year and the rounded-up rate for the same year. The OASDI rate ratio is calculated based on the combined balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust for a specific calendar year. The OASDI rate ratio is determined by the combined balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund at the end of a calendar year, compared to the total amount paid out from these Trust Funds for authorized purposes during that year. The OASDI rate ratio is calculated based on the combined balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund at the end of a calendar year, compared to the total amount paid out from these Trust Funds for authorized purposes during that year. The Security Act is amended to limit reductions in tax rates imposed on employers, ensuring the rate remains above 4.95 percent. This amendment aims to maintain the balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendment limits reductions in employer tax rates to prevent the rate from falling below 4.95 percent. This ensures the balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund is maintained. The text chunk discusses a reduction in the Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance tax rate following a reduction year, with the rate of tax being reduced by a certain percentage. The reduction is limited to prevent the rate from falling below 4.95 percent to maintain balance in the trust funds. The text chunk introduces a reduction in the Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance tax rate, with limitations to prevent it from dropping below 4.95 percent. The text introduces a reduction in the Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance tax rate, ensuring it remains above 4.95 percent. The tax rate imposed under subsection (a) will be reduced by the reduction percentage in years following a reduction year. The reduction is limited to ensure the tax rate remains above 9.9 percent.
